choices.A: This device may be vulnerable to the Heartbleed bug due to the way transactions over TCP/22 handle heartbeat extension packets, allowing attackers to obtain sensitive information from process memory.
choices.B: This device is most likely a gateway with in-band management services.
choices.D: This device may be vulnerable to remote code execution because of a butter overflow vulnerability in the method used to extract DNS names from packets prior to DNSSEC validation.
choices.C: This device is most likely a proxy server forwarding requests over TCP/443.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I'm going B here

Selected Answer: D
Agree with D and CVE posted by jeepTango

Selected Answer: D
Going with D
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-25681

I think the correct answer is B.
The heartbleed bug is an openssl bug which does not affect SSH
Ref: https://www.sos-berlin.com/en/news-heartbleed-bug-does-not-affect-jobscheduler-or-ssh

Selected Answer: C
I am saying C, 

A isnt a lessons learned, what A is talking about are findings.

B & D are a no-go
A & C are possible. 
A = The 'reporting structure' is not a part of lessons learned.. So it's not A. 
C = Client and Pen Team have "Expectations" about processes during the assessment, so I'm going with Answer C.

According to CompTIA's certmaster:
"When you debrief within the penetration test team, you are likely to uncover things that did or did not work well. You can use this information to influence how you conduct future tests. The primary goal of drafting a lessons learned report (LLR) or after-action report (AAR) is to improve your PenTest processes and tools."

It could be A or C, as C states the word "process" which is seen in their documentation, but there's also a process that's followed when to communicate or report with your Team Lead. 

I'd say C, as it's the most vague and wide reaching answer, where as A is one specific circumstance that may fit but is not the only one.
I think this should be A.

choices.A: To provide feedback on the report structure and recommend improvements
choices.B: To discuss the findings and dispute any false positives
choices.C: To determine any processes that failed to meet expectations during the assessment
choices.D: To ensure the penetration-testing team destroys all company data that was gathered during the test

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST describes why a client would hold a lessons-learned meeting with the penetration-testing team?

A penetration tester who is performing a physical assessment of a company's security practices notices the company does not have any shredders inside the office building. Which of the following techniques would be BEST to use to gain confidential information?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If you don't shred confidential documents, they'll be readable intact when they're disposed of.

questions.question_text:
The results of an Nmap scan are as follows:
Starting Nmap 7.80 ( https://nmap.org ) at 2021-01-24 01:10 EST
Nmap scan report for ( 10.2.1.22 )
Host is up (0.0102s latency).

Not shown: 998 filtered ports -

Port State Service -
80/tcp open http
|_http-title: 80F 22% RH 1009.1MB (text/html)
|_http-slowloris-check:
| VULNERABLE:
| Slowloris DoS Attack
| <..>
Device type: bridge|general purpose
Running (JUST GUESSING) : QEMU (95%)

OS CPE: cpe:/a:qemu:qemu -
No exact OS matches found for host (test conditions non-ideal).
OS detection performed. Please report any incorrect results at https://nmap.org/submit/.
Nmap done: 1 IP address (1 host up) scanned in 107.45 seconds
Which of the following device types will MOST likely have a similar response? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
From the http-title in the output, this looks like an IoT device with RH implying Relative Humidity, that offers a web-based interface for visualizing the results.

So, I would choose B (because of port 80) and D

Selected Answer: BD
I think B and D are correct, sloworis attack is related with HTTP (application layer), a networking device does not fit that profile, plus the QEMU OS is related with virtualization and is a bit unorthodox to be used by a networking device. 
https://www.netscout.com/what-is-ddos/slowloris-attacks

Selected Answer: C
Drop tables is SQL ie parameters being used.
